The show examines all aspects of the legal profession, from intellectual property to criminal law, from bankruptcy to securities law, drawing on the deep research tools of BloombergLaw.com and BloombergBNA.com.</itunes:summary><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: MD Assault Weapons Ban Back in Court (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vxe6iP3IKaPs/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vxe6iP3IKaPs/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 21:08:17 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vxe6iP3IKaPs/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: MD Assault Weapons Ban Back in Court (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Adam Winkler, a professor at the UCLA Law School, and Mark Graber, a professor at the University of Maryland Law School, discuss a Maryland assault weapons ban, which is currently being debated before the Fourth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. In February, a three-judge panel of the Fourth Circuit vacated a lower-court ruling, which upheld Maryland's law, but then, a month later, the Fourth Circuit voted to re-hear the case. They speak with Bloomberg Law host June Grasso on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>15:36</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: Antitrust Laws Stop Staples Merger (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vCYKpIezsecM/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vCYKpIezsecM/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 21:08:56 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vCYKpIezsecM/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: Antitrust Laws Stop Staples Merger (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Jennifer Rie, a senior litigation analyst for Bloomberg intelligence, and David McLaughlin, a financial crimes reporter for Bloomberg News, discuss the failed merger between Staples and Office Depot, which was abandoned on Tuesday after a federal judge sided with U.S. Officials challenging the combination of the two office supplies giants. They speak with Bloomberg Law hosts June Grasso and Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>15:36</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law Brief: The World Series of Intellectual Property]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vdBGk4nyjix8/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vdBGk4nyjix8/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 12:28:18 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vdBGk4nyjix8/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law Brief: The World Series of Intellectual Property</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>Jim Gibson, a professor at the University of Richmond School of Law, and Tyler Ochoa, a professor at Santa Clara University law school, discuss the second trial for the high profile case of Oracle vs Google, a match-up that has been called the "world series" of intellectual property cases. This case will determine whether Google made fair use of Java, which was recently purchased by Oracle, when developing the Android mobile operating system. They speak with Bloomberg Law host June Grasso on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>3:48</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: `World Series' of Intellectual Property (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v5Y6G5te5654/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v5Y6G5te5654/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 21:12:46 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v5Y6G5te5654/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: ‘World Series’ of Intellectual Property (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Jim Gibson, a professor at the University of Richmond School of Law, and Tyler Ochoa, a professor at Santa Clara University law school, discuss the second trial for the high profile case of Oracle vs Google, a match-up that has been called the "world series" of intellectual property cases. This case will determine whether Google made fair use of Java, which was recently purchased by Oracle, when developing the Android mobile operating system. They speak with Bloomberg Law host June Grasso on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>16:02</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqAe8IVVZbWw/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 21:09:56 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqAe8IVVZbWw/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: North Carolina Sues U.S. Government (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Steven Sanders, a professor at the Indiana University Maurer school of law, and Katherine Franke, head of the center for gender and sexuality law at Columbia university, discuss North Carolina's lawsuit of the Federal Government over the State's controversial "bathroom bill." The lawsuit comes in response to a justice department letter that said the bill violates the civil rights act. North Carolina governor Pat McCory announced the lawsuit today, calling for a clarification of federal law over restroom policies for public and private employers nationwide. They speak with Bloomberg Law hosts June Grasso and Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>15:50</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law Brief: Randy Barnett on the Constitution]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqETwZL2TYiM/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqETwZL2TYiM/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 12:10:18 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqETwZL2TYiM/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law Brief: Randy Barnett on the Constitution</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg)--Randy Barnett, director of the Georgetown University Center for the Constitution, and Author of "Our Republican Constitution: Securing the Liberty and Sovereignty of We the People," discusses two competing interpretations of "We the People," one that defines "we" as a group of individuals acting independently, a 'republican' interpretation, and another, which sees "we" as a collective entity, the 'democratic' view. Through these two understandings of the first words of the constitution's preamble, Barnett gives a history of how the 'republican' understanding has lost ground among constitutional scholars and judiciaries, giving way to a 'democratic' tradition of jurisprudence. He speaks with Bloomberg Law hosts June Grasso and Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>3:53</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: Barnett on `Our Republican Constitution' (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v4HjeKLDHZVI/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v4HjeKLDHZVI/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 21:04:07 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v4HjeKLDHZVI/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: Barnett on ‘Our Republican Constitution’ (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Randy Barnett, director of the Georgetown University Center for the Constitution, and Author of "Our Republican Constitution: Securing the Liberty and Sovereignty of We the People," discusses two competing interpretations of "We the People," one that defines "we" as a group of individuals acting independently, a 'republican' interpretation, and another, which sees "we" as a collective entity, the 'democratic' view. Through these two understandings of the first words of the constitution's preamble, Barnett gives a history of how the 'republican' understanding has lost ground among constitutional scholars and judiciaries, giving way to a 'democratic' tradition of jurisprudence. He speaks with Bloomberg Law hosts June Grasso and Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>15:58</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law Brief: CFPB Reveals New Arbitration Rules (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vmDODf01kv6o/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vmDODf01kv6o/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 12:18:21 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vmDODf01kv6o/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law Brief: CFPB Reveals New Arbitration Rules (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg)--Quyen Truong, Former Assistant Director and Deputy General Counsel of the CFPB, and a Partner at Strook & Strook & Lavan, and Rafael Mangual, legal policy manager at the Manhattan Institute, discuss new arbitration rules that are being proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The new rules, which are being released today, would target arbitration clauses and allow bank customers to participate in class action lawsuits against the banks. They speak with Bloomberg Law host June Grasso on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>4:02</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: CFPB Proposes New Arbitration Rules (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v6IpZUDKkqRs/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v6IpZUDKkqRs/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Thu, 05 May 2016 21:23:11 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/v6IpZUDKkqRs/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: CFPB Proposes New Arbitration Rules (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Quyen Truong, Former Assistant Director and Deputy General Counsel of the CFPB, and a Partner at Strook & Strook & Lavan, and Rafael Mangual, legal policy manager at the Manhattan Institute, discuss new arbitration rules that are being proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The new rules, which are being released today, would target arbitration clauses and allow bank customers to participate in class action lawsuits against the banks. They speak with Bloomberg Law host June Grasso on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>16:13</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law Brief: Amtrak Regulatory Power Challenged (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vGFa70Y.NjRE/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vGFa70Y.NjRE/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Thu, 05 May 2016 11:57:52 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vGFa70Y.NjRE/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law Brief: Amtrak Regulatory Power Challenged (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg)--Kimberly Robinson, a Supreme Court reporter for Bloomberg B-N-A, and Christopher Paolella, founding partner of Reich and Paolella, discuss a federal appeals court ruling, which has decided that Amtrak, a government-owned for-profit company, should not have regulatory power over an industry that it participates in. A three-member Washington D.C. Appeals court unanimously voted to strike down parts of the 2008 Passenger Rail Investment and Improvement Act, arguing that this infringes on the rights of private freight carriers. They speak with Bloomberg Law host Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>3:48</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: Court Denies Amtrak Regulatory Powers (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vKT6FF75epeE/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vKT6FF75epeE/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 21:18:13 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vKT6FF75epeE/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: Court Denies Amtrak Regulatory Powers (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Kimberly Robinson, a Supreme Court reporter for Bloomberg B-N-A, and Christopher Paolella, founding partner of Reich and Paolella, discuss a federal appeals court ruling, which has decided that Amtrak, a government-owned for-profit company, should not have regulatory power over an industry that it participates in. A three-member Washington D.C. Appeals court unanimously voted to strike down parts of the 2008 Passenger Rail Investment and Improvement Act, arguing that this infringes on the rights of private freight carriers. They speak with Bloomberg Law host Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>16:01</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law Brief: Colorado Fracking Bans Thrown Out  (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vcG9qZSMaKBg/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vcG9qZSMaKBg/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 11:52:54 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vcG9qZSMaKBg/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law Brief: Colorado Fracking Bans Thrown Out  (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg)--Charles Warren, a partner at Kramer, Levin, Naftalis and Frankel, and Stpehen Miller, a professor at the University of Idaho College of Law, discuss a Colorado Supreme Court decision, which ruled that some municipalities' bans on hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, were "invalid and unenforceable." The decisions in uphold lower court rulings and are a blow to cities along Colorado's shale-rich Front Range, which have sought to limit fracking for environmental and safety reasons over the last few years. They speak with Bloomberg Law host June Grasso on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>3:45</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: Colorado Fracking Bans Thrown Out (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vdHPaLW_FyQM/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vdHPaLW_FyQM/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Tue, 03 May 2016 21:07:14 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vdHPaLW_FyQM/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: Colorado Fracking Bans Thrown Out (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Charles Warren, a partner at Kramer, Levin, Naftalis and Frankel, and Stpehen Miller, a professor at the University of Idaho College of Law, discuss a Colorado Supreme Court decision, which ruled that some municipalities' bans on hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, were "invalid and unenforceable." The decisions in uphold lower court rulings and are a blow to cities along Colorado's shale-rich Front Range, which have sought to limit fracking for environmental and safety reasons over the last few years. They speak with Bloomberg Law host June Grasso on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>15:49</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law Brief: Cheerleader Case Goes to High Cour (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vK3eE4K8KtAw/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vK3eE4K8KtAw/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Tue, 03 May 2016 12:53:44 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vK3eE4K8KtAw/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law Brief: Cheerleader Case Goes to High Cour (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg)--Susan Scafidi, founder of the Fashion Law Institute at Fordham Law School, and designer Barry Kieselstein-Cord, founder of Kieselstein-Cord, discuss a Supreme Court case that will establish the scope of federal copyright protection for pictures and graphic designs. In this particular case, Star Athlectica v. Varsity Brands, two cheerleading apparel companies are debating whether Star Athletica stole Varsity's designs, but the case has far more wide-ranging consequences for federal copyright protection for clothing. They speak with Bloomberg Law hosts June Grasso and Michael Best on Bloomberg Radio's "Bloomberg Law."</itunes:summary><itunes:duration>4:04</itunes:duration><itunes:keywords>business, podcasts, law podcasts, legal podcasts</itunes:keywords></item><item><title><![CDATA[Bloomberg Law: Cheerleader Case Goes to Supreme Court (Audio)]]></title><link>http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqDRkwq.5Qwo/v2.mp3</link><guid isPermaLink="true">http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqDRkwq.5Qwo/v2.mp3</guid><pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2016 21:03:35 GMT</pubDate><enclosure url="http://assets.bwbx.io/av/users/iqjWHBFdfxIU/vqDRkwq.5Qwo/v2.mp3" length="0" type="audio/mpeg"/><itunes:author>Bloomberg News</itunes:author><itunes:subtitle>Bloomberg Law: Cheerleader Case Goes to Supreme Court (Audio)</itunes:subtitle><itunes:summary>(Bloomberg) -- Susan Scafidi, founder of the Fashion Law Institute at Fordham Law School, and designer Barry Kieselstein-Cord, founder of Kieselstein-Cord, discuss a Supreme Court case that will establish the scope of federal copyright protection for pictures and graphic designs.
